conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, creating a dark area on a surface behind the object. The size and position of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object.
In the image, there are four shadows labeled A, B, C, and D. Each shadow corresponds to an object above it. The light source is currently positioned such that it casts these shadows on the ground.

premise: When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), several changes occur.
conclusion: The shadows will move forward (away from the light source) on the ground. This is because the angle of light incidence changes, causing the shadows to shift in the opposite direction of the light source movement.

premise: When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), several changes occur.
conclusion: The shadows will generally become larger. As the light source moves farther away, the light rays become more parallel, causing the shadows to elongate.
Shadow A is cast by a cylindrical object.

premise: Shadow A is cast by a cylindrical object. When the light source moves backward.
conclusion: Shadow A will move forward and elongate, becoming larger and more stretched.
